awd_titl_txt: Nuclear Structure and Reactions from Effective Field Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
The fundamental interactions in nuclear physics are described by the theory of Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD). At low energies, QCD is a strongly interacting theory that cannot be solved from first principles in a pencil-and-paper calculation. The effective field theory (EFT) formulation provides a complementary framework where nuclear properties at low energy can be systematically calculated. As such, EFT calculations can provide accurate input for astrophysical models of element synthesis that cannot be obtained in direct experimental measurements. In this project, the PI and his collaborators will use numerical methods defined on a space-time lattice to calculate properties of medium-light atomic nuclei (mass number up to around 40) using EFT. The PI will use Bayesian statistics to quantitatively compare competing EFT formulations. The latter is useful in constructing an accurate and systematic theory for low energy nuclear physics. Broader impacts of the research include training of graduate students in numerical and analytical work for an academic or industry career benefiting society.

The current project builds on the lattice EFT pinhole algorithm that was previously introduced by the PI. This algorithm allows for the calculation of the charge and matter distribution (in the center-of-mass coordinate) in Monte Carlo simulations that is necessary to couple external electro-weak currents to atomic nuclei. The PI aims to calculate electromagnetic moments of light nuclei. The same method will be used to calculate neutrino-nucleus coherent scattering that is sensitive to the neutron matter distribution. This cross section serves as a background in dark matter search experiments.  The PI will study also low energy nuclear reactions involving halo nuclei using Bayesian statistics. Halo nuclei are characterized as weakly bound quantum systems and play an important role in element synthesis in the Big Bang and stellar burning. Bayesian analysis provides a natural framework to incorporate EFT assumptions about naturalness of sizes of couplings in parameter estimation. It also allows quantitative comparison of competing theories and aids in model selection. This project will support the science programs at planned major U.S. investments in rare isotope beam experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: Nuclear reactions during the Big Bang and stellar evolutions determine the abundance of atomic nuclei in nature. Without the atomic nucleus, chemical elements and life itself cannot exist.  Major US investments in experimental sites such as the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB) at Michigan State University explore properties of atomic nuclei that are important in element synthesis. Nuclear theory plays a crucial role in this.

Often the low energies relevant to nuclear synthesis are not directly accessible in experiments due to the Coulomb repulsion of charged particles. Theory is needed to extrapolate and interpret experimental data. The theoretical method of effective field theory (EFT) is crucial in this. It provides a model-independent framework to calculate nuclear properties and reactions with reliable error estimates.

Analytical and numerical methods were developed to calculate nuclear structure and reactions. The numerical methods included defining EFT on a space-time lattice (lattice EFT) that allows calculations of large nuclear systems, intractable by analytical pencil-and-paper methods. The research conducted under the current NSF grant helped develop EFT methods for the treatment of Coulomb forces at low energies.

Outcomes: Analytical methods for EFT calculations in the presence of the Coulomb force reduced previous errors in key solar reactions such as the production of boron-8 nuclei by a factor of 2. Other important reaction rate calculations involving neutron, helium-3, alpha, and lithium-7 nuclei were improved. The application of Bayesian statistical tools in nuclear reaction rate estimates was improved. Results from these studies were used as some of the recommended values in the third decadal community compilation (Solar fusion III) of solar reaction rates.

Lattice EFT methods that are complementary to the analytical EFT calculations were developed. One key outcome was the wavefunction matching algorithm. It simplified the form of the nuclear forces at high energies keeping the relevant physics at low energies of interest intact. This improved the accuracy of the numerical calculations of nuclear properties across a large region of the atomic chart.

Broader impacts: The funds from the NSF grant contributed towards graduate student education and research at Mississippi State University (MSU). The graduate student training in computational science and analytical work has contributed to strengthening the national pool of scientifically skilled workers in the U.S.  The geographic diversity of nuclear physics research in the U.S. was enhanced. Research from this proposal was used in an advanced Quantum Mechanics course at MSU, training a new generation of scientists. The proposed work introduced new methodologies for calculating nuclear reactions in weakly bound systems with reliable error estimates. This ties in well with U.S. investment in rare isotope beam experimental efforts. Dissemination of the results through a website and journal publications has enhanced scientific understanding. The nuclear theory calculations would impact the field of astrophysics.  The field of atomic physics would also benefit from the work done in the weakly bound systems because of the universality that weakly bound nuclear and atomic systems share.
